trans-unit.source: JNDI-specific properties for external directory services

seg-source.mrk: JNDI-specific properties for external directory services

target.mrk: JNDI-specific properties for external directory services

trans-unit.source: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to set a few advanced JNDI properties, which you can set in any of the supported ways of setting <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> properties. Typically you would set these at the same level (database or system) for which you configured the external authentication service.

seg-source.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to set a few advanced JNDI properties, which you can set in any of the supported ways of setting <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> properties.
Typically you would set these at the same level (database or system) for which you configured the external authentication service.

target.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to set a few advanced JNDI properties, which you can set in any of the supported ways of setting <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> properties.
Typically you would set these at the same level (database or system) for which you configured the external authentication service.

trans-unit.source: The list of supported properties can be found in Appendix A: JNDI Standard Environment Properties in the Java Naming and Directory API at <xref format="html" href="http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html" scope="external">http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html</xref>. The external directory service must support the property.

seg-source.mrk: The list of supported properties can be found in Appendix A: JNDI Standard Environment Properties in the Java Naming and Directory API at <xref format="html" href="http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html" scope="external">http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html</xref>.
The external directory service must support the property.

target.mrk: The list of supported properties can be found in Appendix A: JNDI Standard Environment Properties in the Java Naming and Directory API at <xref format="html" href="http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html" scope="external">http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/guide/jndi/spec/jndi/properties.html</xref>.
The external directory service must support the property.

trans-unit.source: Each JNDI provider has its set of properties that you can set within the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> system.

seg-source.mrk: Each JNDI provider has its set of properties that you can set within the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> system.

target.mrk: Each JNDI provider has its set of properties that you can set within the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> system.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can set the property java.naming.security.authentication to allow user credentials to be encrypted on the network if the provider supports it. You can also specify that SSL be used with LDAP (LDAPS).

seg-source.mrk: For example, you can set the property java.naming.security.authentication to allow user credentials to be encrypted on the network if the provider supports it.
You can also specify that SSL be used with LDAP (LDAPS).

target.mrk: For example, you can set the property java.naming.security.authentication to allow user credentials to be encrypted on the network if the provider supports it.
You can also specify that SSL be used with LDAP (LDAPS).
